data.title: send event to save state after 'Add Project Folder' or 'Remove Projec…
data.body:
Fixes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/12495

When we add or remove project folder,  the window's current project path will be changed, then "initialPaths" will be reloaded, it is the best time to save state

/cc @maxbrunsfeld @lee-dohm

data.title: Atom doesn't seem to respect the `atomTestRunner` field in packages
data.body:
## Background and Context

I'm [hacking on an atom package](https://github.com/briandk/latexer). Jasmine 1.3 (which I believe is Atom's built-in spec runner) doesn't support [`and.callThrough()` syntax](http://jasmine.github.io/2.4/introduction.html#section-Spies:_<code>and.callThrough</code) when spying on methods; it uses the [older `andCallThrough()` syntax](http://jasmine.github.io/1.3/introduction.html#section-Spies:_<code>andCallThrough</code).

No matter what I've tried to do to specify an alternate test runner (alternate to Jasmine 1.3), [my spec still fails](https://github.com/briandk/latexer/commit/e6ec543854e4aae549dda7259835131d7c52b10e)
## Expected behavior
1. When an Atom developer specifies a 2.x Jasmine version `atomTestRunner` in their `package.json` file, Atom will use that framework to run tests.
2. When the value for `atomTestRunner` doesn't resolve to a valid path, Atom should [throw an error](https://github.com/atom/atom/blame/b3009f13875df5f1c6b04ea7bea522ca87164243/src/main-process/atom-application.coffee#L649-L654) to StdErr.

refs 2e54ae1e570e66c9467d30986317b8f6e326a548
## Actual Behavior
1. Atom uses the built-in Jasmine test runner; specs raise an error of undefined if you try to, say, chain `.and.callThrough()` on a `spyOn()`, presumably because that syntax wasn't valid in Jasmine 1.3. Changing the syntax to the older `andCallThrough()` appeases the spec runner.
2. Atom uses the built-in Jasmine test runner AND never raises an error

![atom spec fails with undefined error](http://d.pr/i/VmLp+)
## Steps to Reproduce
1. use `package-generator` to generate a new package `my-package`
2. add `atomTestRunner` to the `package.json`:
   
   ``` json
   {
     "name": "my-package",
     "main": "./lib/my-package",
     "version": "0.0.0",
     "description": "A short description of your package",
     "keywords": [
     ],
     "activationCommands": {
       "atom-workspace": "my-package:toggle"
     },
     "repository": "https://github.com/atom/my-package",
     "license": "MIT",
     "engines": {
       "atom": ">=1.0.0 <2.0.0"
     },
     "dependencies": {
     },
     "atomTestRunner": "asdfjkl;"
   }
   ```
3. at the terminal:
   
   ``` shell
   $ cd path/to/my-package
   $ apm test
   ```
4. Verify no error was raised, even though `asdfjkl;` is definitely not the name of a valid test file
## Session Info
### Atom Version

```
Atom    : 1.9.9
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
```
### System Info

```
System Version: OS X 10.11.6 (15G31)
  Kernel Version:   Darwin 15.6.0
  Boot Volume:  Macintosh HD
  Boot Mode:    Normal
  Secure Virtual Memory:    Enabled
  System Integrity Protection:  Enabled
  Time since boot:  4 days 5:09
```

data.title: Focus application on all code paths that open windows in main process
data.body:
I think this should take the application out of “app nap” on macOS, leading to better responsiveness when opening paths from the CLI. Based on my research this morning I'm fairly optimistic that this might be all that is required to solve our issues with intermittent slowness when opening from the command line on macOS.

/cc @maxbrunsfeld @as-cii @damieng

data.title: TokenizedBuffer's did-tokenize and did-invalidate-range don't fire on small buffer changes
data.body:
It's more of a question than a bug report, so sorry in advance.

Looking at https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/tokenized-buffer.coffee (and also testing), it seems when buffer change is smaller than `chunkSize`, `did-tokenize` and `did-invalidate-range` are never fired.

I was wondering if it's a design decision, or a bug.

data.title: Duplicate files while using another editor
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

When a folder (the file doesn't need to be open) is open in Atom and any file within that folder is modified by another editor, Atom will duplicate the file and add an index to the name.

![2016-08-27 11_48_27-github-userscripts](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/136959/18029080/d6e89b02-6c53-11e6-804c-71ae0e1e607a.png)

I'm trying to switch to Atom from another editor. I sometimes switch to the older editor to do things I have not yet learned how to do in Atom. The old editor doesn't update the file content until after I focus on the editor, so I think that is why it doesn't behave in the same manner as Atom. I've noticed that Atom updates all the open files in the background (when the window isn't focused) even when I quickly switch between branches from my bash window.

It would be nice, and maybe even speed up Atom, if there was a setting to only update the open files when the Atom window has focus.

The "autosave" package is disabled. This issue occurs even if I enable it, therefore I don't think it's related to [this post](https://discuss.atom.io/t/atom-creates-duplicate-files/25968).
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open any folder.
2. Edit any file (e.g. "filename.ext") within the same folder in another editor.
3. Look in the folder and you'll find a new file with an index (e.g. "filename(#).ext").

**Expected behavior:**

Only one file should exist; if the content in Atom was unsaved, it should prompt to update and lose previous changes, or maybe it should have saved the changes when focus was lost.

**Actual behavior:**

When Atom sees that a file has changed, it appears to save the file in an attempt to save any changes, but multiple files end up being saved.
### Versions

Atom: 1.9.9
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome: 49.0.2623.75
Node: 5.10.0
OS: Windows 10 x64 [Version 1607](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/12387/windows-10-update-history)

data.title: Whitespace preceding a comment is not the comment itself
data.body:
#12507 ## Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

I reported this issue gandm/language-babel#234 and @gandm very eloquently explained what the underlying cause of the problem is. Rather than attempt to rephrase, I shall simply quote from [here](https://github.com/gandm/language-babel/issues/234#issuecomment-242779428):

> Little bit complex but it appears that [autoflow](https://github.com/atom/autoflow/blob/master/lib/autoflow.coffee#L18) attempts to determine the line that the cursor is on is part of a paragraph. This eventually calls [language-mode](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/language-mode.coffee#L196) which eventually determines [here](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/language-mode.coffee#L212) that this line isn't a comment line because my grammar doesn't set the whitespace preceeding the // as a comment ( **because it isn't!** ) and therefore determines that this line is part of a paragraph including the line above.

Thus, I'm reporting the issue here.

It might be a design decision, and in fact not a bug at all, but intended behaviour, but such considerations are beyond me, so I'm posting here anyway, feel free to close if this is the intended behaviour.
### Steps to Reproduce

Unfortunately I'm not sure if I can make a reproduction now as @gandm has already changed the approach taken by the language-babel plugin which circumvents this issue.
### Versions

Atom    : 1.9.9
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

apm  1.10.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.10
git 2.7.4

xfce4

A side note: I can resize the directory panel on the left, so Its not a bug of my desktop environment. It happens vertically and horizontally. I've also tried this on windows lately and this works. This came with some version of 1.9.x, 1.8.x worked before.

data.title: Incorrect Python folding for indented block followed by triple quoted string
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

With this Python file:

```
if True:
    pass

"""
Text
"""
```

folding the code gives this appearance:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/67612/18023323/dd296cf0-6bac-11e6-8e22-500c0cad7c1e.png)

If the first triple quote has text following on the same line, I get the correct folding:

```
if True:
    pass

""" t
Text
"""
```

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/67612/18023354/415618b8-6bad-11e6-9e53-94e4018dfcf9.png)

I discovered this issue while executing code via Hydrogen - see https://github.com/nteract/hydrogen/issues/418
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Any Python file with block containing indentation followed by a bare triple quote on a line, at the same indentation level as the first statement of the block.
2. Fold the indented block.

**Expected behavior:**

The block containing indentation should fold, but not include the triple quotes.

**Actual behavior:**

The block folds along with the initial triple quotes.
### Versions

```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.9.9
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
$ apm --version
apm  1.10.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.11
git 2.7.4
```

data.title: Graphical glitch after window snapping.
data.body:
First of all, thanks for great work with the editor. It is getting better and better with every release.

I noticed a small graphical glitch that I don't know how to fix. In every Linux distribution I tried, whenever I snap Atom to either left or right side of the screen (Ubuntu or Gnome window snap) a white line appears on the right side of the window (always right no matter which side of the screen I snap it to). The window looks fine when it is not snapped and it is theme independent.

Small thing but would be great if it could be addressed.
![screenshot from 2016-08-27 02-20-54](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18163728/18014372/9dd28770-6bfd-11e6-8f27-cb9c2c837ef5.png)

![screenshot from 2016-08-27 02-21-17](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18163728/18014379/a9b770d2-6bfd-11e6-9524-b31b99973c21.png)

Many thanks!

data.title: Disable telemetry on AtomApplication tests and smoke tests
data.body:
Unless a choice has been made by the user, the telemetry consent tab always shows up as the first one when opening Atom, thus breaking some of the assumptions we make in main process tests. This caused our test suite to be ❌, even if behavior-wise everything was okay.

With this pull-request we disable the telemetry tab in main process and smoke tests, so that the build is 💚 again.

/cc: @atom/core

data.body: _Not an atom issue_

data.title: Ignore next update
data.body:
Each time there's a new version available for Atom, a popup shows when you start the editor and offers two options:
- `Cancel`, closes the popup until you reopen the editor.
- `Go to the download page`, starts a browser with the releases section of the github repository.

With this enhancement a third button would be shown for ignoring the update, meaning that if you reopen the editor the message for the update will not appear until there's a new update.

Simple and effective if you don't need to have the latest version with bug fixes that aren't targeted to your operative system or new features that you won't need.

data.title: Dueling tab length between editor default and languages
data.body:
### Description

When the Atom Editor Settings tab length is set, it is not possible to use a language-specific tab length that matches the language's default. It will assume the "default" value and use the editor tab length instead.

For example, the Atom editor default and LESS language both use a tab length of 2 spaces. If you override the default setting for the editor, it's not possible to force LESS to use 2 spaces, because the editor assumes that you want the default and then falls back to the global editor override.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Set tab length to 4 spaces in Atom Editor Settings.
2. Set LESS language settings to 2-space tabs.
3. Observe that the language settings input resets itself and that the effective tab length when indenting in LESS files is 4 spaces, not 2.

**Expected behavior:** You can force the tab length to be the default value without it resetting.

**Actual behavior:** If the value matches the default, it will reset to the placeholder version of the setting (`Default: 2`) rather than appearing as an override.
### Versions

`atom --version`
apmAtom    : 1.9.9
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

`apm --version`
apm  1.10.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4

OS X 10.11.6

data.title: On Mac clicking Atom icon in a Dock opens multiple windows
data.body:
**Scenario**
- Open Atom
- Close Atom by pressing red X bubble at the top left corner. No you don't have any windows opened just an active Atom icon in the dock
- Click quickly several times on Atom icon in the doc

**Expected** 
- To open only one window despite the fact that I clicked several times

**Actual**
- Opens one window per click. [See screenshot](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/6417398/Screen%20Shot%202016-08-25%20at%2013.29.53.png)

**Info**
- Atom 1.9.9
- Mac OS 10.10.5
